definition:
[**Definition**]{} A set is *uncountable* if it is not countable. In
other words, a set $S$ is uncountable, if there is no subset of
${\mathbb{N}}$ (the set of natural numbers) with the same cardinality as
$S$.

1.  All uncountable sets are infinite. However, the converse is not
    true, as ${\mathbb{N}}$ is both infinite and countable.

2.  The real numbers form an uncountable set. The famous proof of this
    result is based on Cantor’s diagonal argument.
